title: Moving from evidence to policy: prioritising the rights, safety and health of trafficked and asylum-seeking women and girls exposed to violence
abstractText:
We will use study findings on trafficked and asylum-seeking women's vulnerability to influence policies and services to decrease interpersonal and structural violence and improve responses to their health and protection needs in the United Kingdom; Belgium; Italy and at the European Union level. Study results will be used to:

  • Influence European Commission's 'Reception Conditions Directive' of the 'Common European Asylum System' to promote recognition of the special needs of female migrants exposed to violence.
  • Influence implementation of the 'Race, Disability and Gender Equality Scheme by raising awareness of gender disadvantages experienced by asylum-seeking and trafficked women and their special support and protection needs.
  • Inform development of UK 'National Referral Mechanism' (NRM) for Trafficked Persons to ensure UK care and protection plans incorporate measures that are gender and culturally appropriate and respond to abuse.
  • Feedback to asylum-seeking and trafficked women through easy-to-read information sheets that explain study findings and their rights and options for assistance.
  • Increase the awareness among service providers (health, social welfare, legal services) about migrant women's exposure to and the consequences of violence, other health risks and special trauma-informed care needs.
  • Document lessons learned on methods for research impact.
organisation: London Sch of Hygiene and Trop Medicine
